learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of a range of natural hazards.
Research, interpret and synthesize information from a range of sources relevant to the analyses of hazards, risks, vulnerability, resilience, adaptation and management.

Analyse information to gain understanding of hazards and the landscapes in which they exist and thereby allow critical assessments of hazards and approaches to dealing with them i.e. adaptation, mitigation or avoidance; and how to undertake appropriate decision-making.
Communicate knowledge, interpretations and analyses in written, graphical and oral formats effectively and in a manner appropriate to the field.
Understand and use the language, frameworks and tools used in hazard geography and emergency management.
Work cooperatively in a small group to deliver a natural hazards risk assessment report and to make recommendations to stakeholders on risk reduction.

assessments.category: Role play/ Simulation, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
There are four worksheets to complete throughout the semester. Practical recordings will be available to guide students to complete these worksheets. Exercises contain a mix of short questions and brief essays. The exercises are designed to consolidate learning. Questions in the exercises may appear in the final exam.

Worksheet 1: Week 4 practical recording on Floods; submit in Week 5

Worksheet 2: Week 5 practical recording on ENSO; submit in Week 6 (day before Easter holiday)

Worksheet 3: Week 8 online live-streamed practical on Earthquakes; submit in Week 9

Worksheet 4: Week 9 practical recording on Volcano/GIS; submit in Week 10

All worksheets are to be submitted by Friday 16:00 of the week following the respective prac. (except for Worksheet 2: submit on Thursday because Friday is a public holiday)

Students should attend the third online live-streamed practical on "Managing a Disaster" to participate in the role-play activity.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Download the worksheets from Blackboard, answer all the questions, then submit electronically on Blackboard.

assessments.task_description:
The risk assessment report is a GROUP assignment. Students will work in groups to assess the natural hazard risk in a local suburb. Results will need to be collated and synthesised as a written report. Instructions and guiding questions for discussions will be announced in the first online practical and posted on Blackboard. 

Students can form their own groups during the practical. Absentees will be grouped randomly. 

The report should be no more than 5500 words, exclusive of references. 10% of the final mark will be deducted for every 10% excess words. Final marks will be distributed among group members based on the peer assessment scores. The peer assessment form should be submitted individually to Blackboard ("submission" folder) by the same due date. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This group report should be submitted electronically via Turnitin on Blackboard (1 submission per group)

assessments.task_description:
This is an individual assessment item. Students will each select a peer-reviewed journal article on the theme of environmental hazards, published in the past ten years. The article may be related to Climate change projections, Natural hazard trends, or Hazard vulnerability (just some examples). Analyse the article critically and then record a presentation (slides + webcam) covering the section below. The presentation should be no more than 15 minutes.

1. Demonstrate your understanding of the article (weighting: 30%)

  • Synthesise the work by explaining the aims, significance, method, and major findings of the research.
  • Explain how the research and results contribute to hazard risk reduction or the progress of hazard geography

2. Evaluate the article (20%)

  • Critically review the article, e.g. give your comments on the hypotheses, methods, or analyses of the work, based on your knowledge in hazard science or/and disaster management.
  • Give your opinions on how the research or this paper can be improved

3. Relate the research or concepts presented in this paper to the topics in this course and/or to other courses in your program (20%)

  • How does this article fit (or contradict) with the knowledge you have learned so far? 
  • How can you apply the knowledge?
  • Would you recommend this paper to future students taking this course? Why/why not?

4. Design a research project relevant to this paper, pitch the idea in the final part of the presentation (30%) 

  • Describe your project idea, including the motivation, aims, research questions/hypotheses, and explain how such a research project will contribute to the progress the field of hazard-related research.

The second live-streamed practical is a workshop on how to choose a suitable article for this assessment, and how to construct a video presentation for this assignment. Students are to attend this practical to discuss the selection of an article with the course coordinator in person during this practical. 

The video presentation must be presented by the student (not an AI avatar or similar). A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Student will create a video (PowerPoint slides by screen sharing + voice-over + webcam). This can be created using Zoom or Powerpoint. Please submit your video on Padlet AND a submission form via Blackboard.
